stem: The patient is exhibiting signs of increased intracranial pressure (ICP). Review the nursing note below and highlight all findings that support this diagnosis.

itemContext.sbar: S: Jameson Walker, 68-year-old male, admitted at 02:00 today for acute ischemic stroke, right middle cerebral artery (MCA) occlusion. NIHSS score upon admission was 18. B: History of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and atrial fibrillation. Last dose of IV Alteplase completed at 03:30. A: At 07:00, patient's GCS has decreased from 14 to 11. Pupils are unequal; right pupil 6mm and sluggishly reactive, left pupil 3mm and reactive to light. New onset of left-sided weakness. Requires increased oxygen supplementation to maintain SpO2 >94%. BP trending upward. R: Recommend immediate neurological assessment and CT scan of the head without contrast to evaluate for increased ICP and possible hemorrhagic conversion. Consider administering mannitol per protocol. Notify neurosurgery for emergent consultation if ICP continues to rise.

tabs.content: S: Jameson Walker, 68-year-old male, admitted at 02:00 today for acute ischemic stroke, right middle cerebral artery (MCA) occlusion. NIHSS score upon admission was 18. B: History of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and atrial fibrillation. Last dose of IV Alteplase completed at 03:30. A: At 07:00, patient's GCS has decreased from 14 to 11. Pupils are unequal; right pupil 6mm and sluggishly reactive, left pupil 3mm and reactive to light. New onset of left-sided weakness. Requires increased oxygen supplementation to maintain SpO2 >94%. BP trending upward. R: Recommend immediate neurological assessment and CT scan of the head without contrast to evaluate for increased ICP and possible hemorrhagic conversion. Consider administering mannitol per protocol. Notify neurosurgery for emergent consultation if ICP continues to rise.

tabs.title: Labs
tabs.content: Na: 140 mEq/L, K: 4.1 mEq/L, Cl: 100 mEq/L, HCO3: 24 mEq/L, BUN: 18 mg/dL, Creatinine: 1.0 mg/dL, Glucose: 110 mg/dL, INR: 1.2, Platelets: 200,000/uL, WBC: 9,000/uL

tabs.title: Vitals
tabs.content: 02:00: BP 180/100, HR 90, RR 20, SpO2 96% on room air, Temp 37.0째C; 04:00: BP 170/95, HR 88, RR 18, SpO2 95% on room air, Temp 37.2째C; 06:00: BP 190/105, HR 95, RR 22, SpO2 92% on 2L NC, Temp 37.5째C; 07:00: BP 200/110, HR 100, RR 24, SpO2 90% on 2L NC, Temp 37.7째C

tabs.title: MAR
tabs.content: 02:30: Alteplase 0.9 mg/kg IV; 06:00: Acetaminophen 650 mg PO for headache; 06:00: Aspirin 325 mg PO; PRN: Ondansetron 4mg IV for nausea

tabs.title: Nursing Note
tabs.content: 07:00: Patient assessed. Level of consciousness decreased; GCS now 11 (Eyes 2, Verbal 4, Motor 5) compared to 14 on admission. Pupils unequal; right pupil 6mm and sluggishly reactive to light, left pupil 3mm and reactive. New onset of left-sided weakness noted (1/5 motor strength). Patient reports headache. Requires increased oxygen supplementation to maintain SpO2 >94%. BP elevated to 200/110. No seizure activity observed. Acetaminophen administered for headache. Neurologist notified.

rationale.correct: The highlighted findings directly indicate increased ICP. A decreasing GCS (Level of consciousness decreased; GCS now 11 (Eyes 2, Verbal 4, Motor 5)) indicates worsening neurological function. Unequal pupils (Pupils unequal; right pupil 6mm and sluggishly reactive to light) suggest pressure on the oculomotor nerve. The need for increased oxygen (Requires increased oxygen supplementation to maintain SpO2 >94%) is due to possible respiratory compromise secondary to brainstem compression. Elevated blood pressure (BP elevated to 200/110) is the body's attempt to maintain cerebral perfusion (Cushing's Triad). New onset of weakness (New onset of left-sided weakness noted (1/5 motor strength)) indicates increased pressure on motor pathways. These are all critical signs that the patient's condition is deteriorating and requires immediate intervention.
rationale.incorrect: Acetaminophen administration, although relevant to patient care, does not directly support increased ICP. While headache is a symptom of increased ICP, it is a subjective complaint and not an objective finding. Neurologist notification is an appropriate action but not a direct assessment finding. The patient's report of a headache may be related to increased ICP, but it is not as direct and objective as the other findings.
clinicalPearls: Cushing's Triad (bradycardia, irregular respirations, and widened pulse pressure) is a late sign of increased ICP, indicating imminent brain herniation.
Early recognition of increased ICP is crucial to prevent irreversible brain damage and improve patient outcomes. Monitor for subtle changes in LOC and vital signs.
Maintain the head of the bed at 30 degrees to promote venous drainage and reduce ICP. Avoid activities that increase ICP, such as coughing or straining.

questionTrap.trap: Focusing solely on the stroke diagnosis instead of recognizing the signs and symptoms of increased ICP, a complication of the stroke, can lead to delayed intervention.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Carefully analyze each finding and consider its relationship to increased ICP pathophysiology. Remember the compensatory mechanisms and the signs of decompensation. Prioritize objective findings over subjective complaints.

mnemonic.title: I-ICP
mnemonic.expansion: Irritability, Increased BP, Changes in LOC, Pupil changes
